description.text: 2015-06-25 / Ok, I think I've found my new favorite clip here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:635200

I really liked the "Yet Another Filament Clip" by palawanisland and also the "Filament Clip for Spools!" by Bassna.  
The filament grabbing part of "Filament Clip for Spools!" is great, but these always get knocked off the spool since they grab on the side and my spools are always rubbing elbows with the other spools.  
The "Yet Another Filament Clip" method of going under two loops is also great, but I found its filament grabbing part not grabbing quite as much as I liked, so I basically drew a new part that mashes them both together.
I printed with 20% infill and it works well.  More infill is always stronger, of course.

comments.text: Ok, I like these except they stick up too much and get knocked off. My new favorite clips are here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:635200

title: Segway I / X Series Kickstand Bracket.

description.text:
If you have a Segway you probably know they failed in the kickstand engineering department. The original kickstand for these models came with a spring which easily became broken or bent beyond repair.  This was a "safety" feature so that if the kickstand fell down while gliding it didn't catch the ground and send the rider flying through the air.  Unfortunately though the spring was too weak and collapsed under the weight of the Segway while parked.  A genius then came up with a  metal tube replacement for the spring and then started selling them.  This decreased the safety, but actually let you "park" the Segway.  Unfortunately this increased the stress on the actual kickstand bracket and as a result of using the metal tube replacement the bracket can get broken especially if you try to mount the segway and forget to remove the kickstand.  The bracket can also get broken if the kickstand falls down while gliding, it catches something while gliding, or somebody pushes on your Segway while parked.
As a result of all this I broke two of the "pot" metal brackets and nearly a year later of having a partially finished CAD model of the bracket sitting on my hard drive; I finally finished it.
You will need Metric hex keys (Allen wrench), Torx #25 bit and M6 tap to tap the bolt hole.

comments.text: This is great! I foolishly threw my kickstand away after it broke. :(
comments.author: hellphish

title: Printrbot Plus GT2 upgrade Belt clips

description.text:
Designed this part for my Printrbot Plus V2 to upgrade the stock belt to a GT2 belt in solidworks. It holds the belt in place, and also replaces the stock belt tensioners. If you use this, please leave a comment and what printer you have.  
I bought my belt and pulleys on ebay for about $30 shipped.

Print 4 of these before doing your upgrade, and I used an exacto knife to clean up the edge that holds the belt (so its not a knife)  
While installing, rotate the wood piece that holds the x-axis motor 90 degrees to allow the belt to have clearance.   
I bought my belt and pulleys on ebay for about $30.

author: nickswimsfast

description.text:
(EDIT 5/17/2012: License changed to CC SA (was CC SA NC))  
Printed Parametric Chainmail  
I've been wanting to try this for a while.  This is a sheet of interlocking rings, printed in place.  The rings are basically square, with cut off corners.  Two sets of diagonals cross each other at different heights, with four posts at the corners.  Well, it makes sense when you see the pictures!  
This is the first thing I've designed in OpenSCAD, so the code is probably pretty sloppy.  The major parameters that can be changed are the layer thickness and line width, along with ring size and number.  
I searched for "chainmail" on Thingiverse and the only result was a post by Vik on the Interlocking Rings thing: "Next, chainmail. Right?" So I hope you like this, Vik!

Summary:

  • Change parameters in OpenSCAD file and export a single ring as STL, OR use included Chainmail 1x1.stl file. It uses default parameters of .25mm layer thickness and .5mm line width.

  • Use multiply plugin in skeinforge, 4x4 or 8x8 are good places to start, 16x16 will fit on a Makerbot but is more difficult

  • If you are printing raftless, the bed needs to be very flat and level

  • Remove from bed by scraping from edges
    • Alternately, you can try exporting the grid as an STL first, but watch out for the travel moves between extrusions. Long version: This is actually a pretty ridiculous thing to print. A stepper extruder is probably required, sorry. I ran into a few problems along the way and it took me some time to get it to print right. The first issue was patterning the rings to make a sheet. After I had one ring designed in OpenSCAD, it was easy to add some code with parameters to create a grid. I tweaked the spacing using a 4x4 grid with no trouble. However, when I went to 16x16, it took a full 2 hours to compile and render! Since this is the first time I've used OpenSCAD, maybe an expert can tell me if there is something I can do to speed things up. I had skeinforge process my 16x16 STL which went quickly, since it is only 6 layers. I proceeded to print and was dismayed to see the print head zooming around the printing area, seemingly at random. It had done a remarkably poor job at calculating the travel paths between the print roads. In most cases this wouldn't matter, but the first two layers of the chainmail consist of a huge number (512 for 16x16!) of tiny bean shaped extrusions. Every time the extruder passes over a piece that has already been printed, there is a chance that it will be ripped up, which ended up happening frequently and ruining the print. This might just be an issue with the old version of skeinforge I'm using; other versions might work better. The solution I found was to use the multiply plugin in skeinforge to create the grid. With the default parameters as used in the STL file (.5mm layer thickness, 2.0 perimeter width/thickness), I found that a setting of -4 worked well for Separation over Perimeter Width. The print order still isn't optimal but it's a huge improvement. I printed raftless, at low speed. The print bed needs to be very flat and level, especially for bigger pieces. It took me a few tries to get the ideal thickness on the first layer. I also dropped the flow rate by 10%. I removed the chainmail sheet using a sharp razor blade, very slowly working in from the edges. You can fold the loose edge over to make it a little easier. To join multiple sheets, you will probably have to painstakingly cut a row of rings and then glue them back together. I haven't gotten to that point yet. For reference, I printed this on a RapMan 3.0 using Ultimachine PLA. Dimensions: Chainmail 1x1: 7.8mm x 7.8mm x 1.5mm (single ring) Chainmail 4x4: 23.85mm x 23.85mm x 1.5mm Chainmail 8x8: 88.05mm x 88.05mm x 1.5mm The final stretched sheet dimensions will be slightly greater, due to gaps needed for printing. So far, my best print is the black one shown in the first picture. 255 out of 256 rings are intact!

title: Printrbot Plus V2 Z-axis nut holder

description.text:
If you run the printrbot stock out of the box the Z-axis nut can slip out, and you will lose your z-axis calibration, and unlevel your print head relative to the bed.  
This little part loosely holds the bottom of your nut so the axis won't pop off. Simple fix. Nothing fancy, just a simple part to improve my machine, and I'd thought I'd share.

title: Case for the Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller

description.text: This is a case for the Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller. http://www.reprapdiscount.com/home/34-full-graphic-smart-lcd-controller.html

As on my other enclosures: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35438
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79820
I tried to design a slim enclosure again using a channel outside between the top and bottom part to let the case apear more flat - and, to cover possible impressisions ;-).
I recommend to print the parts in different colors.
To fasten the controller board to the bottom part, first put the distance cylinders between the boards and use metrical screws M3 x 12 (14).
Both will work without tapping before.
There is no room for hexagonal pockets in the top part. You can screw M3 x 16 directly into it.
The second bottom part contains several screw nut deepenings for fastening the case as you like. If you mount it to an 8 mm rod you can use the case clamps.
If the cables are plugged in, the case inevitably has a slope of 6°. In case you need more slope:
I'm already thinking about a base that can be screwed below the housing.
If you are interested, look out for this thing which I will publish separated. And yes, don't forget to assemble the distance cylinders - the display's bord won't like it ;-)

I picked up a FGD from RRD and wanted to print out this slick case. But I noticed that I could not get it to close well. Also, the spacers were about 1.75mm too short to be of any good. It seems that the spacing between the LCD board and the main board has increased by about 1.75mm---at least in the version I got from them. This is an official unit from RRD.
This is pretty easy to fix on my end (just need to extend the size of the lid) but just wanted everyone to be aware that there is a mismatch in size with recent FGDs from RRD.
If you just got a FGD and want to build this case, make sure you measure the distance between the LCD board and the main board with a caliper. If your distance is around 4.5-4.6mm, then you will have some problems getting the case to fit.

description.text: life bar by w.gelech [created on 3DTin]

As part of the XRobots Challenge by James Burton, people are asked to design new ways to assemble a costume that can be done by one person fairly quickly.
This is my answer.

So this design is broken down in to various parts that need to be glued together. It was also design to be 6 cm wide at the most so there is a need for accurate scaling.
These are the instructions so far.
1)The idea is that the 4 fabric mounts get glued into the fabric mount holder.
2) The flat side of the fabric mount holder get glued to the bearing mount. (you need two of these)
3) now assemble the inner and outer bearing lock.
4) glue a bearing mount holder to each of the two inter locking pieces.
5) install the bearings
6) snap together the pieces and you should be done. This design is a work in progress and please feel free to add comments and print this out yourself.

comments.text: So I just made printed the inner and outer locking mechanisms and there appears to be some tolerance errors. Please hold on as these parts are under frequent change.

These springs have only been tested on Greg Frost's Hinged Extruder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8252 (as a replacement to the idler springs), although may be useful as a replacement for other springs. Having said that I have also found it useful as a dampener to allow some play with my z motors, while keeping them firm and steady. The silicone is a small ellipsoid shape cut from a Silicon pot holder from a "$2 shop", which has a small hole for a bolt to pass through. Initially this particular item caught my eye due to the claimed temperature durability, although I have not considered it for any hot applications yet.

With a 4mm drill bit (this was an arbitrary choice), drill into one of the ellipsoid bits of silicon. With a drill, the holes end up looking like cuts, but the will stay firmly on the bolt or screw. Alternatively, you could use a punch, but would need to be small and a very hard strike with a hammer.
Cut out the piece you want, and place onto bolts, or otherwise, with washers on each side.
For my z motors, as my motors only have two places to secure with, I have slid the other two pieces under the motors on the adjacent corners. Although this was partially circumstantial, and part laziness on my part for not wanting to fully remove the motors, I think this is good arrangement anyway (short of having 8 pieces) as it keeps the z motors and/or the screws/bolts from directly pushing against the z motor mounts (in an up or down direction), hence allowing some play with the motors.

title: Automatic Print Ejector - The Punching Machine

description.text:
Achieve 3D printer autonomy by adding an Automatic Print Ejector to your machine. This mechanism will knock the printed part off the bed when it is finished printing. We like to call it the punching machine, Check the video above to see why. For a complete component list and assembly instructions head to this write up: http://www.matterhackers.com/store/digital-designs/automatic-print-ejector-the-punching-machine Developed by the MatterHackers Engineering Team - the Punching Machine gives your printer the ability to remove the printed part from the bed without any human interaction. See it in action Here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Viy928RLsdU
  • Printing Recommendations -
    • All parts were printed with MatterHackers Pro Series PLA. http://www.matterhackers.com/store/3d-printer-filament?t=1.75mm%20PRO%20Series%20PLA Recommended Print settings:
  • Layer Height: 0.2 mm Layers
  • Perimeters: 2 Perimeters
  • 30% Infill

Head here for detailed instructions including wiring diagrams and code: http://www.matterhackers.com/articles/learn-how-to-punch-pesky-prints-off-the-bed-with-the-automatic-print-ejector COMPONENT LIST (What you will need)
Printed Parts: http://www.matterhackers.com/store/digital-designs/automatic-print-ejector-the-punching-machine
1×NEMA 17 Stepper Motor
1×Polulu Stepper Motor Driver
1×OpenBeam 24 cm Extrusion
34×623ZZ Ball Bearings3mm ID, 9.5mm OD
14×M3 x 12 Bolts
2×M3 x 20 Bolts
18×M3 x 8 Bolts
30×M3 Nuts
20×M3 Washers Thanks to the designers of the boxing glove (http://www.123dapp.com/123c-3D-Model/Boxing-Gloves/592887) and wades small gear (https://github.com/nophead/Mendel90/blob/master/mendel/stls/wades_small_gear.stl) for the use of the parts/modified parts in our final machine.

description.text: MatterControl Touch Stand MatterControl Touch is the ultimate upgrade for your 3D printer - an Android-powered touchscreen controller that turns your 3D printer into a truly independent, internet-connected device. MatterControl Touch gives you the ability create, edit and prepare models directly on your printer using a simple touchscreen interface. It includes an onboard camera, an easy to use interface and wireless internet capabilities. Check it out here: http://www.matterhackers.com/store/printer-accessories/mattercontrol-touch

Ok, this might sound dumb, but I don't want to use a Servo for my Z probe for the Prusa i3.  So I made this stick.  In the end of the stick is a small hole where I glued in a small micro push-button switch.  The probe attaches to the hot-end holder that mounts to the X carriage.  I'm uploading the 123d design source file too.  Measure the thickness of your hot-end mount (the horizontal piece) and then use the "Press-pull" to change the inner width of the F shape.  More pics later....

description.text: Allows for mounting lightweight accessories made for 15mm rods w/ 60mm spacing on studio hardware that uses 15m rods at 100mm spacing. Perfect for light accessories, such as a follow focus. Designed with FreeCAD. Source files available on Github: https://github.com/fdiebel/studio-rod-adaptor

I printed with PLA filament on the following settings, and results were okay.
  • Layer height: 0.22
  • Walls: 2.05
  • Fill: 50
    • There was a very slight bit of flex with my follow focus mounted but not enough to affect pulling focus. I'll probably try printing with different settings/materials and see if that makes any difference. The 15mm mounts on the lower support will likely be a slightly tight fit on your support rods; sand the inner wall if needed. To finish the project, you will need 2 M4 nuts and 2 ~20mm M4 bolts, preferrably with wing nuts for easy hand-tightening.

Oh! I meant to design a motor mount for stepper57 to build a Kossel delta printer. In its design I made a mistake (thing 870010) as the U-Notch should face opposite! I made the necessary modification here. Of course the early thing would be useful for other uses! :-)

I saw schmarty's clever Volumetric Tentacle Key Hook ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8720 ), which struck me as right up the alley of my extrude-place-by-function doodles in OpenSCAD. When I looked at guru's original Volumetric Tentacle, I saw that indeed, he had used essentially the same methods but in Processing. So I made a clone of his work, in OpenSCAD, just to show it could be done. OpenSCAD can do organic looking, there... you just have to be patient with the renders!

The script is definitely not parametric, so fiddle at your own risk :-) Rendering took 3+ hours, and the STL was 6+ MB. I ran it thru netfabb with came back with a much more reasonable 1.5 MB. GitHub repository: https://github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects/tree/master/Tenta-Clone

Two gears for use in TechBox Challenge.

A little adapter to allow you to mount a 3/8"-16 standard microphone mount to a 1/4"-20 standard tripod.   
Print both pieces, install a 3/8"-16 x 1/2" bolt in the base, install a 1/4"-20 nut inside the spacer in the bottom of the base. Glue/epoxy the whole thing together being careful to protect the threads.  
The parts fit tightly together from my printer, may be slightly looser on others.
Why printing an acorn? Because my kid wants one ... and it was fun to make.
Print the three parts, apply some super glue and ... well, enjoy?

Very much a work in progress, ImplicitCAD does not seem to output .stl/.obj files that slic3r likes. Also I dont think the pen would grab the lead well. pen.stl provided went through meshlab using the 'Surface reconstruction poison' remeshing with octtree depth 10. (..Which isnt perfect, it changes the surface, i think ) Slic3r does some funky things(it might be the model) at the bottom, probably want to watch the start of the print, so you know it doesnt come off. I was annoyed by all the delays largely caused by software stuff so i decided to just publish the WIP. Development version at github NOTE: the thingiview is slow on this one

title: MatterControl Touch Mount for Robo R1

description.text: MatterControl Touch Stand for your Robo R1. What is MatterControl Touch? MatterControl Touch is the ultimate upgrade for your 3D printer - an Android-powered touchscreen controller that turns your 3D printer into a truly independent, internet-connected device. MatterControl Touch gives you the ability create, edit and prepare models directly on your printer using a simple touchscreen interface. It includes an onboard camera, an easy to use interface and wireless internet capabilities. Check MatterControl Touch out here: http://www.matterhackers.com/store/printer-accessories/mattercontrol-touch https://www.matterhackers.com/store/digital-designs/mattercontrol-touch-mount-robo-3d-r1

Add a few drops of essential oil to the mix and after a few days your object will smell like that instead of vinegar. Have fun.

I have stabbed myself on occasion by discovering an X-acto knife dropped carelessly in a drawer.  When I saw the "Wall mounted xacto holder" by jeremygold, I knew I wanted a pegboard version.

Print fairly solid so that the legs are strong. I print my pegboard designs with supports for those upward curving legs.  Some people have reported that they can print them without supports.  My luck with that has been mixed.  
The legs are spaced so they'll be intentionally tight. Rock it back and forth gently to get it to seat in the pegboard.

I wanted to design a foot so I could raise my Mendel off the desk, without having to take it apart. I came up with what I like to call the Elephant Foot. I think it looks a lot like one. I eventually want to come up with a leveling foot that is all one piece but for now I will stick with this.

Download the file and print four of them. 
Optional:
I used a 1/4-20 x 3/4" machine screw and nut that I screwed in from the top that will allow you to level your Mendel. Simply adjust the height of each screw until the machine is level.
I cut out a 1/4" thick neoprene gasket with adhesive backing that I stuck to the bottom of each foot to help with vibration. I also have a 1/4" thick piece of neoprene on the bottom of each frame vertex.

comments.text: When I saw this I initially thought it was referring to elephant foot suspension: http://www.ukro.org/CMS/nat2010/UKRO_Heavy_Vehicle_Construction_Lo_Res.pdfhttp://www.ukro.org/CMS/nat201... (search for elephant to see a pic).

title: Folgertech 2020 Prusa i3 X belt tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yes, another x belt tensioner for a Prusa i3 - this one is specifically designed to fit the Folgertech 2020 Prusa i3 version with the chamfered holes in the carriages. All the others I found had rectangular parts that would not fit the Folgertech version right. This one also reuses the stock flanged bearings the kit comes with.   
I did add a washer on either side to make sure movement of the bearings was smooth, and needed a slightly longer screw to mount the bearings.

Printed in ABS, 0.3mm layer height, high infill (70% minimum recomended for strength. no supports necessary. added vitamins:
For bearings:
1 - M3x20 screw for bearings (longer than stock)
2 - M3 washers (optional)
For tensioner
1 - M3x25 (30) screw
1 - M3 washer
1 - M3 nut to reduce the chance of it cracking, i did use acetone on the bearing side ends to make sure everything was nice and solid. Please note: You may need to adjust your X endstop a little, depending on how long your belt ends up.

description.text: This is a modified version of the nexus 4 bumper cover.  I had to make some alterations that I thought would make for a better case and print.

This was printed with ABS and no supports.  I printed it with thermal activated color changing ABS.  This makes for a really fun print.  The heat of the phone will show as well as the heat from your hands.

This is a bearing race for a thrust bearing. It just needs two M8 washers and 8 x 4.5mm (0.177") ball bearings of the kind normally fired from BB guns. It was designed for the bearings of the RepRap Darwin Z axis, but is a generally useful little widget. Including washers, it occupies approximately the same space as a 608 bearing.
A set of 4 of these bearings has been in constant use for 1 1/2 years with no issues.

I print these on a 1-layer raft, then just clear the holes with a 5mm and then 8mm drill held in the hand. 
Fit a washer onto the M8 axle, and put the race on top. Load one BB into each hole and sandwich with another washer.
Thick grease or vaseline stops premature discharge of the BBs. They can be printed in most plastics including PLA, ABS and CAPA.

comments.text: It works just fine in a Darwin Z axis without a 608 bearing. I ran mine for more than a year until I built a couple of Mendels with it. The Z bearings are still good.
comments.author: vik

comments.text: This is a thrust bearing and should not be used to replace a 608 but instead it should be used in the Darwins Z axis in conjunction with a 608 or a roller bearing for the lateral loads as a 608 bearing is not ideal for side loads.

comments.text: I'm not very sure about the mechanical durability of PTFE tape to constant motion. My guess is it'll come to bits. Threading it all in woul dbe a challenge too. I've been using the same set for over a year in the Child/Phoenix and the PLA is hardly marked at all - despite the TSA's best attempts.

comments.text: Have you considered making the holes a tiny bit bigger for the bearings, then wrapping the actual printed part(or maybe just the parts in contact with the beraing) in ptfe tape. Basically loop the tape around the parts and thread it through the bearing holes. it probably would take a while, but it might eliminate the requirement for grease or vaseline because the bearings would not be wearing away the race.

title: Parametric Spool Mount for Prusa Mendel

description.text: This is a spool mount for the Prusa Mendel to use with the Parametric Filament Spool. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8317 This spool mount only uses one piece of M8 thread (or SAE equivalent) and two M8 nuts. The M8 rod I had was a bit long but you can use a shorter piece. I would recommend a piece 20cm or longer.

• Print
  • Slide the lower mount onto the top two threaded rods on your Prusa and tighten it on with two M8 nuts.
  • Screw your piece of threaded rod into the lower mount. If it is hard to do by hand counter tighten two nuts on the thread so you can turn the thread with a wrench.
  • Screw the upper spindle piece onto the threaded rod.
  • Snap on the frame piece.

description.text:
With the biointensive method of gardening, vegetables are planted in an equal-spaced hexagonal or triangular pattern, instead of in straight rows. I made this planter to assist in planting seeds that should be 6 inches apart with the biointensive method. I used the planting spacer for soybeans this spring.  
Place the planting spacer on your garden bed, drop one seed in each of the holes, and then move the spacer so that the two leftmost holes align with the two rightmost seeds that you just placed. Put two new seeds in the rightmost holes and repeat as necessary.  
The spacer can be scaled to accommodate different spacings, such as 2", 3" or 4" spacings.

description.text:
These four locks grip the leveling thumbscrews of the Printrbot LC to prevent undesired rotation as the build platform jiggles in operation.  
I recommend a dab of hot glue on the heads of the leveling machine screws (under the Y carriage) to keep them from rotating.

All four locks are included in the STL file.  Drop them down over the thumbscrews to lock them in place.  They are easily removed for further adjustment.  
These locks fit my Printrbot LC.  OpenSCAD source provided so you can modify for machines of slightly different dimensions.  
Note that front and rear locks have different dimensions.  Left locks are mirror images of right locks.  Front locks are positioned +X in the STL file, but will be installed -Y on your Printrbot.

My female dog is an escape artist. She will constantly apply pressure to the kennel door until she eventually gains her freedom. Luckily, she almost never needs to be in her crate anymore. I made some design changes as well as original prints of the plastic cover covering the spring locking mechanism on my crate. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dT9Vc-2z9iM Kennel_Original.stl - original cover. no changes, just a replacement part. Kennel_Straight_Shaft - Modified design to allow for a completely different locking method (home depot bought metal release shaft) Kennel_Tensioner - This is a spring less design that allows you to still secure your dog with the absence of the original springs. title: Mini V-Tail Copter (based on EMaglios TriCopter)

description.text:
It started with EMaglios Tricopter, which surely will get a classic! I had so much fun building and flying this tri-copter, so I decided to try 'MoRayCHs' v-tail modification. My Up! mini can only print 120x120x120mm, so I used the splited parts from 'omegatron' in both cases.
Having a little chat with maker 'DaWoJnA' brought me a better solution to attach the arms. I do not need the FPV features, so I decided to close the corresponding holes. Knowing that it's getting really warm inside the copter, I made some (as I think) more efficient air intakes. The arms have openings to hold M3 nuts, attaching them is now much easier and safer than before.
I splited the arms in two sections, arm and motor mount. These can now be printed in their ideal position for stability. The same happened with the tail. Here I closed the cable inlet for the not needed servo and widened the upper inlet for the additional motor power cables. I glued the parts first an welded the seams with an soldering iron afterwards. Notice!! All parts are compatible to the original ones, so you can select the best combination for your needs. So f.ex. it is possible to use the original body from EMaglio with the new arms from here. Finally I can tell you, that this little thing is a TERRIFYING BEAST. It's so fast and agile, I think it will take some time to master this copter. Even finding the right PID settings will be a challenge (I hope naze32s autotune will help). I have flight times with an 1300mAh LiPo of round about 9 minutes. I'd like to thank again the above mentioned members/makers for their work and I would be very happy to see YOUR make!
Made a little clip today, while testing and optimizing PIDs -> https://youtu.be/vjhLBizUo8I

07.25. Update
Joined the lower and middle body sections on request. They are available for download.
BTW: If you like my contributions and designs, feel free to send me a TIP ... ;o)

comments.text:
I can only give you a link to a german shop but you can find these FCs in every location. There are two versions of the Naze32 controler available, the "Acro" and the "Full". The Full has some more features onboard but the Acro is good enough to keep copters with 2 to 8 motors flying. If you are totally new to this theme, you should find a good forum or online source for informations about programming and wiring, because you'll have many questions - I promise they are not hard to find.
You can find the Naze here for example -> http://www.rctech.de/flugelektronik.html

comments.text:
Hi, I don't think that it'll make sense if you try to use my PIDs, because every copter needs its own settings an the multiwii will not work with settings from the naze32 afaik. Especially the I-Value works different. Have you tried the basic values?
What is the problem when you try to lift off? Have you checked the propellers and motors for their direction? What setup do you use (motors, ESCs, battery,...)? Which mode do you use? Have you done all the calibrations?
I'd say that if the copter does not hover/lift off while using the basic values, then there is something wrong with your setup
comments.author: Highlander36

comments.text:
emax 1804 2450 Kv

spektrum 6210 RX
Naze32 Full Board (GPS, BORO, MAG)
3s 1300mah lipo
Front Left motor direction = clockwise
Front Right motor direction = anti-clockwise
Rear Left motor direction = Anti-clockwise
Rear Right motor direction = clockwise
directions match the cleanflight motor config pic for a v-tail quad.
naze board is aligned 90' to the craft and the corresponding setting changed in setup, the GUI model responds correctly to the movement of the quad.
transmitter sticks centered to 1500 with a range of 1000 - 2000.
props are nylon 6*3 CW and CCW
first flight I had it 2 - 3 feet off the ground but it was unstable so landed and altered the PID's
P settings:-

comments.text:
Ok I think that looks fine. Have you tried the autotuning? For me it worked very well(!). There are very good tutorials about this feature on youtube/the web.
You should use it in Angle-Mode, no other helpers activated. You'll find out that the MAG is not very good and Baro only works, if you protect the onboard sensor with a little piece of foam (!).

I turned the rear propellers knowingly upside down (like they would be normaly mounted to the motors), so that the upper side points to the ground. comments.author: Tomalinski

comments.text:
If you look at the makes you can read that ianroy uses 1806 2300KV and his copter is flying very well and has enough power.
What is the weight of your copter at lift off? How did you attach the naze? Is it possible that the receiver gives vibrations to the naze? The naze is a little sensitive on vibrations. I used a double-sided sticking foam (2-3 mm) as it is used for mirrors to reduce the vibrations.
comments.author: Highlander36

comments.text: got it into the sky today, and went though the auto tune sequence which helped slightly, and i'll upload two videos so you can take a look, its was almost impossible to get it to yaw on the stick and the fish tailing is still there though not as bad, when trying to get it to yaw the tail motors "howl" which you can hear in one of the videos.
comments.author: Tomalinski

comments.text: I have to admit that this is really strange ...especially the fast descending in the first vid. Can you post the actual PIDs please? I'll ask some (copter-) friends what they think about your videos, maybe they'll have a solution. Looking at your vids I personally think that it's a combination of incorrect PID settings and something with the motors or ESCs. How did you teach the ESCs? All together with the CF-GUI or one by one over the transmitter?
comments.author: Highlander36

comments.text: I calibrated the ESC's all at the same time with the cleanflight GUI, batt unplugged, master throttle to max, batt then plugged in, and after the beeps dropped master to min, all motors start up at the same time, there is almost no response while yawing on the stick but as you can hear the tail motors oscillating left and right fighting to keep it straight, when pulling back on the stick to pitch up the tail motors "howl" as if at max rpm! I have posted my New PID settings after auto-tune on my make page.
comments.author: Tomalinski

comments.text:
Ok I posted the essence of our brainstorming and your vids to a german copter-community, I'm curious about the input from there.
I watched your clips several times and I think that your PIDs are to high, especially the P and the D. The "howling" seems to result out of the naze's attemps to stabilize the copter, but much to agressiv. So the fish-tailing could result out of a to high P.
comments.author: Highlander36

comments.text:
had a break though last night, after you saying you thought it was a problem with either the motors, ESC's and PID's, I stripped it all out and started again and rebuilt the electronics side, did all the calibration of the throttle on the ESC's and transmitter adjustments then tested it but still the same !! then a friend asked me to check the Configuration settings ON the ESC's, so I borrowed his programming card and checked all four!! one of the tail ESC's was configured differently to the other 3 and had "Active Breaking" enabled, so I disabled it and tried it.. and it flies lol very little "fish tailing". now I had not altered the configuration on the ESC's from the factory settings except the throttle calibration though CL, so i'v done a little PID "P" tuning for YAW = 3.0 was 9.8, PITCH = 2.5 was 4.1 just got ROLL left to do now then let auto tune lock them in a bit better.
thank you very much for all your help couldn't have sorted it without your advice!!
comments.author: Tomalinski

comments.text: Hi, I have both, the full and the acro, and the full was the one I had not in use with an other vehicle at that time. Both are very equal but the full has some more sensors like a barometer for example. But these are not really required and sometimes make trouble. The real difference makes the software you'll use for the board. I tried Cleanflight and Baseflight  and stayed with the first. The improvements come faster and CF has some more features.

comments.text: For mine I ended up printing in PLA but used ABS glue (abs + acetone in a ja). Keep adding abs and letting it dissolve until it starts to become thick enough to brush on with a cotton bud or small craft paintbrush, then coat the edges before sliding them together and give the whole join a few coats that run out about 1cm on each side.

description.text: Test prints are important but having just a 20mm cube is boring. Need to test some circles to in the same print.

comments.text: Used this to finally clear the repetitious extruder jam error on my Z18.  This is a nice straightforward object for a test print.  0.2mm layer height, 215 degC, 10% infill, PLA, raft setting, 2 shells.  Essentially the default mode for Z18.
comments.author: SteveMaier_
